query-string

Parse and stringify URL query strings

ðŸ”¥ Want to strengthen your core JavaScript skills and master ES6?
I would personally recommend this awesome ES6 course by Wes Bos. You might also like his React course.

Install

$ npm install --save query-string

Usage

```js const queryString = require(â€˜query-stringâ€™);

console.log(location.search); //=> â€˜?foo=barâ€™

const parsed = queryString.parse(location.search); console.log(parsed); //=> {foo: â€˜barâ€™}

console.log(location.hash); //=> â€˜#token=bada55cafeâ€™

const parsedHash = queryString.parse(location.hash); console.log(parsedHash); //=> {token: â€˜bada55cafeâ€™}

parsed.foo = â€˜unicornâ€™; parsed.ilike = â€˜pizzaâ€™;

const stringified = queryString.stringify(parsed); //=> â€˜foo=unicorn&ilike=pizzaâ€™

location.search = stringified; // note that location.search automatically prepends a question mark console.log(location.search); //=> â€˜?foo=unicorn&ilike=pizzaâ€™ ```

API

.parse(string, [options])

Parse a query string into an object. Leading ? or # are ignored, so you can pass location.search or location.hash directly.

The returned object is created with Object.create(null) and thus does not have a prototype.

arrayFormat

Type: string
Default: 'none'

Supports both index for an indexed array representation or bracket for a bracketed array representation.

  • bracket: stands for parsing correctly arrays with bracket representation on the query string, such as:

js queryString.parse('foo[]=1&foo[]=2&foo[]=3', {arrayFormat: 'bracket'}); //=> foo: [1,2,3]

  • index: stands for parsing taking the index into account, such as:

js queryString.parse('foo[0]=1&foo[1]=2&foo[3]=3', {arrayFormat: 'index'}); //=> foo: [1,2,3]

  • none: is the default option and removes any bracket representation, such as:

js queryString.parse('foo=1&foo=2&foo=3'); //=> foo: [1,2,3]

.stringify(object, [options])

Stringify an object into a query string, sorting the keys.

strict

Type: boolean
Default: true

Strictly encode URI components with strict-uri-encode. It uses encodeURIComponent if set to false. You probably donâ€™t care about this option.

encode

Type: boolean
Default: true

URL encode the keys and values.

arrayFormat

Type: string
Default: 'none'

Supports both index for an indexed array representation or bracket for a bracketed array representation.

  • bracket: stands for parsing correctly arrays with bracket representation on the query string, such as:

js queryString.stringify({foo: [1,2,3]}, {arrayFormat: 'bracket'}); // => foo[]=1&foo[]=2&foo[]=3

  • index: stands for parsing taking the index into account, such as:

js queryString.stringify({foo: [1,2,3]}, {arrayFormat: 'index'}); // => foo[0]=1&foo[1]=2&foo[3]=3

  • none: is the default option and removes any bracket representation, such as:

js queryString.stringify({foo: [1,2,3]}); // => foo=1&foo=2&foo=3

.extract(string)

Extract a query string from a URL that can be passed into .parse().

Nesting

This module intentionally doesnâ€™t support nesting as itâ€™s not specâ€™d and varies between implementations, which causes a lot of edge cases.

Youâ€™re much better off just converting the object to a JSON string:

js queryString.stringify({ foo: 'bar', nested: JSON.stringify({ unicorn: 'cake' }) }); //=> 'foo=bar&nested=%7B%22unicorn%22%3A%22cake%22%7D'

However, there is support for multiple instances of the same key:

```js queryString.parse(â€˜likes=cake&name=bob&likes=icecreamâ€™); //=> {likes: [â€˜cakeâ€™, â€˜icecreamâ€™], name: â€˜bobâ€™}

queryString.stringify({color: [â€˜taupeâ€™, â€˜chartreuseâ€™], id: â€˜515â€™}); //=> â€˜color=chartreuse&color=taupe&id=515â€™ ```

Falsy values

Sometimes you want to unset a key, or maybe just make it present without assigning a value to it. Here is how falsy values are stringified:

```js queryString.stringify({foo: false}); //=> â€˜foo=falseâ€™

queryString.stringify({foo: null}); //=> â€˜fooâ€™

queryString.stringify({foo: undefined}); //=> â€˜â€™ ```
